IV <u>Variations</u>

44 <u>Variations in size</u>. _  We have already seen diversities
both in the <u>diameter</u> and in the <u>thickness</u> of the disk, arise
directly from the degree in which the animal substance (whereon
the skeleton is modelled) has extended itself either <u>horizontally</u>
or <u>vertically</u>, so as to multiply either the number of concentric rings, or
the number of the superposed segments of which each ring consists. This
however, is not the only source of variation in size; for a most
extraordinary diversity presents itself in the dimensions of the
individual components, by whose repetition the entire disk
is made up. It is in the nucleus, that I find this diversity
most strongly marked; as will appear from a comparison of
the twelve figures on Plate IX, which exhibit a gradational
series from the smallest to the largest forms I have met with; all
of them accurately drawn under the same magnifying power
from specimens in my possession x[<u>Note</u>.x Of these figures, Nos. 1.2.3.4.5. 10 and 12 represent entire specimens, whilst Nos. 6.7.8.9. and 11 are
the central portions of larger disks] The length of the entire nucleus
of Fig.12 is about <u>seven</u> times that of the nucleus of Fig.1, and its breadth
about <u>four</u> times as great; the area of the former is therefore about 28 times
